caseTitle: REBECCA NAADU NARTEY v. SOLOMON J. A. NARTEY & 4 OTHERS
summary: The case involves a dispute over the intestate succession of the estate of the late Moses Tetteh Afutu Nartey, a Ghanaian barrister. The plaintiff, Rebecca Naadu Nartey, filed suit seeking equitable distribution under PNDCL 111, accounting for estate assets, cancellation of improper property transfers, and removal of unauthorized structures. The defendants, including the deceasedâ€™s nephew, sister, and children, filed a belated Statement of Defence that the trial court found to disclose no reasonable defence. Despite being granted leave to amend their pleadings, the appellants failed to do so for nearly a year. The trial court entered judgment in default of pleadings and later affirmed it based on evidence led. The Court of Appeal found procedural irregularities, particularly in the trial court hearing evidence before pleadings were complete and without fixing a time for amendment. It held that this violated the audi alteram partem principle of natural justice. Consequently, the Court allowed the appeal, set aside the judgment, and ordered a retrial to ensure fair hearing.
citations: OKOFOH ESTATES LTD vrs. MODERN SIGNS LTD & ANO (1996-97) SCGLR. 224
ATTORNEY GENERAL vrs. TIMES NEWSPAPERS LTD. (1973) Q.B.D. 710
EDWARDS vrs. PHEUMATIC TYRE CO. (1900) 16 T.L.R. 309
rationaleHighlights: The trial court violated audi alteram partem by hearing evidence before pleadings were closed.
Granting leave to amend without time limit rendered the process unfair when judgment followed.
Judgment entered in default of pleading was procedurally flawed due to prior admission of evidence.
The court must not mix summary procedures with full trial evidence without proper closure of pleadings.
Indolence of appellants did not excuse procedural impropriety by the trial court.
